para.paratext: Any person properly served with a subpoena must appear as commanded unless exempted by statute.[1] For example, members of the Georgia General Assembly do not have to obey a subpoena while the General Assembly is in session.[2]

O.C.G.A. §§ 24-13-60 to 24-13-62 allows the superior court to issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum in a civil case to secure the presence in any court of record of a witness who is a prisoner.[3] In a criminal case, the superior court's order for production of the prisoner is sufficient to secure attendance. The person who appears to testify must be the person for whom the subpoena was issued or the person appearing will be subject to criminal penalties.[4]

There are certain protections available for those who are subpoenaed to court such as O.C.G.A. § 34-1-3 that protects employees. It is unlawful for an employer or his agent to threaten or penalize an employee whose presence is required at a judicial proceeding.[5] Additionally, under O.C.G.A. 24-13-1, “a witness shall not be arrested on any civil process while going to or returning from and attending on any court. An officer who holds him imprisoned after seeing his subpoena or being satisfied of the fact shall be liable for false imprisonment.”[6] Under O.C.G.A. § 16-10-93, anyone who attempts to deter a witness from testifying in a court, administrative proceeding, or before a grand jury, shall be shall be guilty of a felony.

A court cannot compel the attendance of a witness who is beyond its jurisdiction. However, the Uniform Act to Secure the Attendance of Witnesses From Without the State[7] provides a process by which a party may summon a witness from beyond his state's jurisdiction for a criminal proceeding. The Act requires that a judge in the demanding state certify to a judge of a court of record in the county in which the witness is found that the witness is a “material witness” in a criminal proceeding whose presence will be required for a specified number of days.[8] The burden of establishing that the witness is material enough to the case to be compelled to travel to a foreign jurisdiction is upon the party desiring the witness.[9]

The Supreme Court has held that the trial court's determination of a requested witness' materiality under the out-of-state-witness Act is a fact-finding proceeding within the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 24-1-2(b); however, the determination is made solely by the trial judge and therefore the rules of evidence, other than privileges, do not apply when the determination is to be made solely by the trial court as a preliminary question concerning the qualification of a person to be a witness under O.C.G.A. § 24-1-104(a).[10]

The Act treats requests for production of out-of-state documents the same as requests for out-of-state witnesses provided that a party seeks testimony from the witness who should be compelled to produce the document. The Act does not allow a request for documents only.[11] It may be difficult to show that a document is necessary and material.[12]
Logan v. Chatham County, 113 Ga. App. 491, 148 S.E.2d 471 (1966).

O.C.G.A. § 24-13-29 states that no member of the General Assembly of Georgia shall be compelled to attend and give testimony at any hearing or trial or to produce evidence while the General Assembly is in regular or extraordinary session.
In Brand v. State, 154 Ga. App. 781, 270 S.E.2d 206 (1980), the trial court erred in not granting a habeas corpus ad testificandum for four prisoners.

In Glover v. Scott, 210 Ga. App. 25, 435 S.E.2d 250 (1993), an employer terminated an employee who missed work pursuant to court order to attend her child's juvenile court proceedings. The court found that the employee was entitled to unemployment compensation, despite having been warned that she would be fired if she were absent or tardy again due to previous attendance problems, because the termination was specifically for her final absence.
The application of this rule is considered in detail in Turner v. McGee, 217 Ga. 769, 125 S.E.2d 36 (1962).

Davenport v. State, 289 Ga. 399, 711 S.E.2d 699 (2011) (appropriate statutory scheme to be employed to analyze defendant's request for certificate requesting attendance in Georgia of out-of-state witness in prosecution for DUI was whether out-of-state witness was a “material witness” in defendant's prosecution, not whether sought-after witness was a “necessary and material witness to the case”; whether out-of-state witness was a “necessary and material witness to the case” is determination to be made by judge in the county where the out-of-state witness is located).

Parker v. State, 296 Ga. 586, 769, 769 S.E.2d 329 (2015). The Supreme Court granted certiorari to determine whether the trial court committed error in excluding hearsay testimony offered by the defendant in a DUI case, where the defendant was trying to have out-of-states subpoenas issued. The Court of Appeals correctly held that the trial court's determination of the requested witness' materiality under O.C.G.A. § 24-13-90 was a fact-finding proceeding within the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 24-1-2(b). However, the trial court erred in sustaining the hearsay objection offered by the state, and the Court of Appeals was reversed in upholding its decision, since the issue was to be decided by the trial court as a preliminary matter to the admissibility of evidence pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-1-104 and is thus an exception to the hearsay rule pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-1-2(c)(1).
French v. State, 288 Ga. App. 775, 776, 655 S.E.2d 224 (2007); Wollesen v. State, 242 Ga. App. 317, 529 S.E.2d 630 (2000).

In Yeary v. State, 302 Ga. App. 535, 537, 690 S.E.2d 901 (2010), judgment vacated on other grounds, 289 Ga. 394, 711 S.E.2d 694 (2011), the appellate court upheld the trial court's denial of a motion for production of out-of-state evidence where there was nothing in the record showing that the requesting party identified or sought to obtain testimony from a witness.

In Davenport v. State, 303 Ga. App. 401, 693 S.E.2d 510 (2010), judgment vacated on other grounds, 289 Ga. 399, 711 S.E.2d 699 (2011), the court held that a DUI defendant was not entitled to production of the source code from the out-of-state manufacturer of the machine used to test her breath sample, despite her argument that her asthma condition affected her intoxilyzer result, because she failed to offer medical testimony about the impact asthma had on her breathing capacity.
